Definition: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return refers to a congenital malformation in which all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium, but instead drain abnormally to the right atrium.
Synonyms: Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, Total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage

Definition: Inability of the left ventricle to perform its normal physiologic function. Failure is either due to an inability to contract the left ventricle or the inability to relax completely and fill with blood during diastole.
Synonyms: Impaired left ventricular function, Left ventricular dysfunction, Left ventricular failure, Left ventricular impairment, Left-sided heart failure

Definition: A congenital malformation of the pulmonary valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Synonyms: Dysplasia of pulmonary valve, Pulmonary valve dysplasia

Definition: Reduced time for the PR interval (beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex). In adults, normal values are 120 to 200 ms long.
Synonyms: Electrocardiographic short PR interval, Short P-R interval, Shortened PR interval on EKG

Definition: An abnormal increase in magnitude of the pressure in the right atrium.

Term: Complete heart block with broad QRS complexes
Definition: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at a relatively low part of the conduction system (below the atrioventricular node), which produces a wide QRS complex.
Conduction block in the posterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.
Synonyms: Left posterior hemiblock

Definition: Subvalvular stenosis is caused by a diaphragm-like membrane. The stenosis is clinically manifested like any other form of aortic stenosis but is often associated with some aortic insufficiency.
A congenital malformation of the aortic valve characterized by leaflet deformation.
Arteriosclerosis occurring at an age that is younger than usual.

Term: Complete heart block with narrow QRS complexes
Definition: A type of third degree heart block in which the escape rhythm arises at the atrioventricular node, which produces a narrow QRS complex.
Failure of the tricuspid valve to close sufficiently upon contraction of the right ventricle, causing blood to regurgitate (flow backward) into the right atrium.
Synonyms: Tricuspid insufficiency, Tricuspid valve regurgitation

Definition: Reduction of the diameter of the coronary arteries as the result of an accumulation of atheromatous plaques within the walls of the coronary arteries before age of 45.
Synonyms: Premature coronary artery disease

Definition: The presence of a bicuspid pulmonary valve.
An abnormal dilatation of lymph vessels in the pericardium.

A longer than normal interval (corrected for heart rate) between the Q and T waves in the heart's cycle. Prolonged QTc can cause premature action potentials during late phase depolarizations thereby leading to ventricular arrhythmias and ventricular fibrillations.

A reduced ejection fraction and an enlarged left ventricle chamber, the latter by an increased resistance to filling with increased filling pressures. Systolic dysfunction is clinically associated with left ventricular failure in the presence of marked cardiomegaly.

Synonyms: Dislocated knee since birth

Definition: Abnormally flat shape of the heads of the metatarsal bones.
Synonyms: Flattened head of long bone of foot

Definition: A sensation of stiffness in the joints that occurs following waking up in the morning.
Synonyms: Generalised morning stiffness

Definition: Interphalangeal joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in the interphalangeal joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity.
Synonyms: Stiff hinge joints

Term: Aplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
Definition: Absence of the abdominal musculature.
Synonyms: Absent abdominal musculature

Definition: A recurrent infection of the GI tract with helicobacter pylori, a gram-negative, microaerophilic bacterium usually found in the stomach.
The occurrence of the full-thickness tear (perforation) of the wall of the esophagus.
Synonyms: Spontaneous esophageal rupture

Definition: Cyst-like space not lined by epithelium and contained within the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts are often associated with pancreatitis.
Hypertrophy of the stomach.
Watery voluminous diarrhea resulting from an imbalance between ion and water secretion and absorption.
Synonyms: Secretory diarrhoea

Definition: The presence of cyst of the intrahepatic bile duct.
Underdevelopment of the colon.
Synonyms: Hypoplasia of the colon, Underdeveloped colon

Definition: Leukoplakia is a precancerous dermatosis of mucous membranes analogous Leukoplakia is basically a chronic inflammatory hypertrophy in which anaplasia and malignant dyskeratosis may develop and subsequently advance to an invasive squamous cell cancer. The clinical diagnosis of primary anal leukoplakia is indicated by single or multiple slightly raised,irregular, marginated, grayish-white keratinized' patches in the anal canal. Tissue biopsy is necessary for confirmation.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition lesions in the pancreas.
Synonyms: Pancreatic calcifications

Definition: Blockage or impairment of the normal flow of the contents of the intestine towards the anal canal.
Synonyms: Bowel obstruction, Intestinal blockage, Intestinal obstruction

Definition: Increased susceptibility to Giardia lamblia infection of the intestine, as manifested by a medical history of multiple episodes of Giardia lamblia intestinal infection.
An abnormal reduction in the ability to masticate (chew), i.e., in the ability to crush and ground food in preparation for swallowing.
Synonyms: Chewing difficulties, Chewing difficulty, Difficulty chewing

Definition: The presence of a fistula (abnormal tunnel) between the anal canal and the perineum.
Absence of gastric intrinsic factor, which is normally produced by the parietal cells of the stomach, and is required for the absorption of vitamin B12.
Synonyms: Intrinsic factor absent from gastric juice

Definition: The presence of multiple diverticula of the intestine.
A collection of pus in the area of the rectum.
Synonyms: Perirectal abscess

Definition: Accumulation of cell free, noninflammatony fluid within the wall of the intestinal tract producing uniform thickening of the mucosal folds.
Synonyms: Intestinal oedema

Definition: Presence of multiple adenomatous polyps in the colon.
Synonyms: Multiple adenomatous colon polyps, Multiple colonic adenomatous polyps

Definition: Obstruction affecting the biliary tree.
A chronic form of gastritis.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the pancreas.
The presence of a hypoplastic gallbladder.
Synonyms: Hypoplastic gallbladder

Definition: A developmental defect resulting in abnormal closure, or atresia of the tubular structure of the jejunum.
A form of chronic pancreatitis that is characterized by calcification.
The presence of degenerative changes of the liver.
A congenital defect characterized by the lack of ganglion cells in the entire intestine, i.e., the aganglionic segment comprises the entire large and small bowel.
Atresia in the extrahepatic bile duct.
Synonyms: Biliary atresia, extrahepatic

Definition: Failure to form of portions of the abdominal musculature.

Synonyms: Death of digestive organ tissue due to poor blood supply, GI infarctions

Definition: Developmental hypoplasia of the intestine.
Synonyms: Hypoplastic intestines, Underdeveloped instestine

Definition: A type of gastritis characterized by excessive proliferation of the gastric mucosa and diffuse thickening of the gastric mucosal folds.

Term: Hypoplasia of the abdominal wall musculature
Definition: Underdevelopment of the abdominal musculature.
Synonyms: Abdominal muscular hypoplasia

Definition: Atresia in the intrahepatic bile duct.
Synonyms: Bile duct paucity, Intrahepatic atresia of biliary duct
Increased anterioposterior diameter of chest
Small chest on one side, Underdeveloped chest on one side

Definition: Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor.
Synonyms: Pectoralis minor aplasia

Term: Unilateral absence of pectoralis major muscle
Definition: Aplasia (congenital absence) of the pectoralis minor on only one side of the chest.
Synonyms: Unilateral aplasia of pectoralis major muscle
Small chest, Small thorax
Small/absent pec muscle, Underdeveloped/absent pec muscle

Term: Abnormal facility in opposing the shoulders
Definition: Increased range of shoulder movement related to aplasia or hypoplasia of the clavicles that results in the ability to approximate the shoulders in front of the chest.
Hemorrhage occurring within a joint.
Synonyms: Bleeding within a joint, Hemarthroses, Hemarthrosis, Joint haemorrhage, Spontaneous joint haemorrhage, Spontaneous joint hemorrhage

Definition: The presence of inflammation of the gastric mucous membrane.
Synonyms: Stomach inflammation

Definition: An abnormality of the gallbladder.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the gallbladder, Anomaly of the gallbladder

Definition: An abnormality of the jejunum, i.e., of the middle section of the small intestine.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the jejunum

Definition: A discrete abnormal tissue mass that protrudes into the lumen of the intestine and is attached to the intestinal wall either by a stalk, pedunculus, or a broad base.

Term: Premature delivery because of cervical insufficiency or membrane fragility

Definition: A pregnancy that ends at a stage in which the fetus is incapable of surviving on its own, defined as the spontaneous loss of a fetus before the 22th week of pregnancy.
Synonyms: Early fetal demise, Spontaneous abortion

Definition: Exaggerated bulkiness of the crease or fold of skin running from the lateral margin of the nose, where nasal base meets the skin of the face, to a point just lateral to the corner of the mouth (cheilion, or commissure).
Synonyms: Deep laugh lines, Deep nasolabial crease, Deep nasolabial fold, Deep nasolabial groove, Deep smile lines, Nasolabial crease, prominent, Prominent laugh lines, Prominent nasolabial groove, Prominent smile lines

Definition: Lack of the cartilage of the nasal septum.
Synonyms: Absent nasal septal cartilage, Absent nasal septum, Ageneis of nasal septal cartilage
Large nasal tip, Large tip of nose, Prominent nasal tip, Prominent tip of nose, Pronounced nasal tip, Pronounced tip of nose
Cartilaginous nasal ossification
Decreased size of nasal tip, Decreased size of tip of nose, Hypoplasia of tip of nose, Small nasal tip, Small tip of nose, Underdevelopment of nasal tip, Underdevelopment of tip of nose

Definition: Posterior positioning of the nasal root in relation to the overall facial profile for age.
Synonyms: Depressed bridge of nose, Depressed nasal bridge, Depressed nasal root, Flat bridge of nose, Flat nasal bridge, Flat nasal root, Flat, nasal bridge, Flattened nasal bridge, Low nasal bridge, Low nasal root, Retruded bridge of nose, Retruded nasal bridge
Decreased size of bridge of nose, Decreased size of nasal bridge, Hypoplastic bridge of nose, Small bridge of nose, Small nasal bridge
Absent bridge of nose, Absent nasal bridge, Agenesis of bridge of nose, Agenesis of nasal bridge, Missing bridge of nose, Missing nasal bridge

Definition: Abnormality of the nostril.
Synonyms: Abnormal naris morphology, Abnormality of the nares, Abnormality of the nostrils, Anomaly of the nares
Anomaly of the nasolabial region
Decreased size of internal carotid artery, Small internal carotid artery

Term: Intimal thickening in the coronary arteries

Synonyms: Poorly functioning veins

Definition: A separation (dissection) of the layers of an artery.

Pseudocoarctation is a congenital anomaly of kinking, or buckling, of the aorta without a pressure gradient across the lesion. It is characterized by elongation and kinking of the aorta at the level of the ligamentum arteriosum.
Peripheral arterial stenosis with onset before the age of 50 years.
A rare congenital vascular anomaly that results when the left superior cardinal vein caudal to the innominate vein fails to regress.
Synonyms: PLSVC

Definition: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the carotid arteries.
Synonyms: Tortuous carotid arteries

Definition: Calcification, that is, pathological deposition of calcium salts in the arch of aorta.

Synonyms: Underdeveloped lung veins

Definition: Formation of a blood clot (thrombus) inside a cerebral vein, causing the obstruction of blood flow.
Synonyms: Blood clot in cerebral vein, Cerebral thrombosis, Cerebral vein thrombosis

Definition: The presence of a capillary hemangioma, which are hemangiomas with small endothelial spaces.
Synonyms: Capillary hemangiomata, Strawberry birthmark

Definition: A type of vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessel walls) affecting large arteries such as the aorta and branches of the aorta.
A developmental defect characterized by the lack of formation of the pulmonary blood vessels.
Synonyms: Absent lung vessels

Definition: Formation of excess fibrous connective tissue in the tunica intima (innermost layer) of arteries in the pulmonary circulation.

An arterial lesion that is characterized by either intimal fibroplasia, with neointimal lesions of cells and matrix deposition, or medial fibroplasia, in which there is loss of smooth muscle cells and increased deposition of collagen and proteoglycans in the medial layer.

Term: Anomalous branches of internal carotid artery

Definition: Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) more than 3 wood units, as defined by the current definition of pulmonary hypertension. 95% of individuals have a PVR of less than 2.4 wood units.
Inflammation of the blood vessels within the brain.

Synonyms: Lack of facial fat below the skin

Definition: A type of craniofacial dysostosis associated with abnormalities of the external ears, mirognathia, macrostomia, coloboma of the lower eyelid, and cleft palate. This is a bundled term that is left in the HPO now for convenience with legacy annotations but should not be used for new annotations.
Synonyms: Treacher Collins syndrome
Prominent nasal septum, Prominent septum of nose

Definition: Unilateral overgrowth of facial tissues, including muscles, bones and skin.
Synonyms: Enlargement of half of face, Facial hemihypertophy, Hemifacial enlargement, Hypertrophy of half of face, Increase in size of half of face, Overgrowth of half of face

Definition: An abnormality of the gestures or movements executed with the facial muscles with which emotions such as fear, joy, sadness, surprise, and disgust can be expressed.
Synonyms: Disturbance of facial expression

Term: Extension of hair growth on temples to lateral eyebrow
Definition: A pattern of hair growth in which there is hair extending from the temples to the lateral eyebrows.
Synonyms: Unusual hairline with hair growth on temples extending to lateral eyebrow

Definition: Underdevelopment of the philtrum.
Synonyms: Small philtrum
Loss of facial expression

Definition: A degree of wrinkling of the facial skin that is more than expected for the age of the individual, leading to a prematurely aged appearance.
Synonyms: Aged facial appearance, Premature aged appearance, Prematurely aged face, Prematurely aged facial appearance, Wizened face
Fixed facial expression, Unchanging facial expression

Definition: Recurrent partial dislocations of the mandible.

Synonyms: Sleepy facial expression, Somnolent facial expression
Darkening of the forehead

Definition: Decreased density/number and/or decreased diameter of lateral eyebrow hairs.
Synonyms: Lateral hypoplasia of eyebrows, Lateral thinning of eyebrows, Laterally sparse eyebrow, Laterally sparse eyebrows, Limited hair on end of eyebrow

Definition: An abnormality of the complement system.
Abnormal bladder function (increased urge or frequency of urination or urge incontinence) resulting from abnormal functioning of the autonomic nervous system.
Underdevelopment of the urinary bladder.
Synonyms: Hypoplastic bladder, Underdeveloped bladder

Definition: Any structural abnormality of the carotid arteries, including the common carotid artery and its' arterial branches.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the carotid arteries

Definition: An abnormality of the structure of the veins that return deoxygenated blood from the body into the heart, i.e., the superior vena cava and the inferior vena cava.

Synonyms: Abnormal facial expression

Definition: Tracheal cartilaginous sleeve (TCS) is a rare congenital airway malformation in which distinct tracheal rings are replaced by a continuous cartilaginous segment. Vertically fused C- or O-shaped cartilaginous rings can extend from the subglottis to the carina or bronchus with little to no pars membranacea posteriorly.\nComment:Tracheal cartilaginous sleeve has been associated with various craniosynostosis syndromes.
Inspiratory stridor is a high pitched sound upon inspiration that is generally related to laryngeal abnormalities.
Hypoplasia of the epiglottis.
Synonyms: Hypoplastic epiglottis

Definition: A primary immune deficiency that is characterized by defects or deficiencies of T-lymphocytes that causes specific susceptibility to intracellular micro-organisms.
Synonyms: Severe T-cell immunodeficiency

Definition: Increased susceptibility to herpesvirus, as manifested by recurrent episodes of herpesvirus.
Synonyms: Susceptibility to herpesvirus

Definition: Complete inability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
Synonyms: Absent cellular immunity

Definition: A reduced level of the complement component Factor I in circulation.

Reduced functionality of the process in which a precursor cell type acquires the specialized features of a B cell. A B cell is a lymphocyte of B lineage with the phenotype CD19-positive and capable of B cell mediated immunity.
Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination.
Synonyms: Absent thymus, Athymia

Definition: Increased susceptibility to chicken pox, as manifested by recurrent episodes of chicken pox.
A general term referring to a defect in immunity resulting from impaired antibody production.
A severe form of B lymphocytopenia in which the count of B cells is very low or absent.
Synonyms: Absent B cells

Definition: Increased susceptibility to streptococcus pneumoniae infections as manifested by a history of recurrent infections by streptococcus pneumoniae.
An abnormality of the humoral immune system, which comprises antibodies produced by B cells as well as the complement system.
Synonyms: Defective humoral immunity

Definition: A reduced level of the complement component Factor H in circulation.
An abnormality of the physiological functioning of B cells.
Synonyms: Abnormality of B cell physiology, Reduced B cell function

Definition: An immunodeficiency characterized by defective cell-mediated immunity or humoral immunity.
Increased susceptibility to Haemophilus influenzae infections as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by Haemophilus influenzae.
Synonyms: Recurrent H. influenzae infections

Definition: Recurrent infections by Neisseria meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis), which is also known as meningococcus.
Synonyms: Increased susceptibility to neisseria meningitidis infections

Definition: A reduced ability of a B cell to become activated, i.e., the change in morphology and behavior of
Increased susceptibility to protozoan infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of protozoan infection.

A group of phenotypically heterogeneous genetic disorders characterized by profound deficiencies of T- and B-cell function, which predispose the patients to both infectious and noninfectious complications.

Term: Depletion of components of the alternative complement pathway
Definition: An abnormal reduction in the components of the alternative complement pathway, such as the C3 protein or its cleavage products.

Increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infection by opportunistic agents, i.e., by microorganisms that do not usually cause disease in a healthy host, but are able to infect a host with a compromised immune system.
Synonyms: Frequent opportunistic infections

Definition: Increased susceptibility to coronavirus 229e, as manifested by recurrent episodes of coronavirus 229e.
An abnormal reduction of the cell motility of neutrophils.
An increased susceptibility to candida infections, as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of candida infections.
Synonyms: Frequent candida infections

Definition: An abnormally low count of T cells.
Synonyms: Decrease in T cell count, Decrease in T cell number, Decreased numbers of circulating T cells, Low T cell count, Reduced number of T cells

Definition: An abnormal increase from the normal count of B cells.
Synonyms: Increase in B cell count, Increase in B cell number, Increased number of B cells

Definition: Increased susceptibility to bacterial infections of the skin, as manifested by recurrent episodes of infectious dermatitis.
Synonyms: Recurrent bacterial skin infections, Recurrent cutaneous pyogenic infections, Recurrent episodes of impetigo, Recurrent episodes of infectious dermatitis, Recurrent pyogenic skin infections

Term: Decreased proportion of CD4-positive helper T cells
Definition: A decreased proportion of circulating CD4-positive helper T cells relative to total T cell count.
Synonyms: Abnormality of CD4+ T cells, CD4 T cell lymphopenia, CD4+ T-cell lymphopenia

Definition: Persistent overgrowth of Candida albicans in the gastrointestinal tract.

An abnormally increased level of circulating alpha-globulin. Alpha globulins are a group of serum proteins defined by their mobility on serum electrophoresis. The alpha1-protein fraction is comprised of alpha1-antitrypsin, thyroid-binding globulin, and transcortin. Ceruloplasmin, alpha2-macroglobulin, and haptoglobin contribute to the alpha2-protein band. The alpha2 component is increased as an acute-phase reactant.

Term: Decreased proportion of CD8-positive T cells
Definition: A decreased proportion of circulating CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells relative to total number of T cells.
Synonyms: CD8+ T-cell lymphopenia, Decreased proportion of CD8+ T cells, Decreased proportion of CD8-positive, alpha-beta T cells

Definition: A reduced level of the complement component factor B in circulation.
Synonyms: Decreased serum factor b

Definition: Decreased or impaired activation of T cells in response to a mitogen, cytokine, chemokine, cellular ligand, or an antigen for which it is specific.
Synonyms: Decreased T lymphocyte activation, Decreased T-cell activation, Decreased T-lymphocyte activation, Defective T cell activation, Profound depletion of T4+ lymphocytes

Definition: Increased susceptibility to infection by gram-negative bacteria, as manifested by a medical history of repeated or frequent infections by these agents.
A reduced level of the complement component C3 in circulation.
Synonyms: Decreased serum C3, Decreased serum complement C3 level

Definition: Lack of detectible CD8-positive T cells
Synonyms: Absence of CD8+ T cells

Definition: An abnormality of the functioning of any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
Absence of specific immunoglobulins directed against a specific antigen or microorganism.
An increased susceptibility to infections involving both the paranasal sinuses and the lungs, as manifested by a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
Synonyms: Chronic sinopulmonary infection, Recurrent sinus and lung infections

Definition: Increased susceptibility to systemic pyogenic infections, as manifested by recurrent episodes of systemic pyogenic infections.
Recurrent infections by bacteria of the genus Neisseria, including N. meningitidis (one of the most common causes of bacterial meningitis).
Synonyms: Episodes of neisserial infection, Recurrent neisseria infections

Definition: At birth, newborns are endowed with maternal antibodies. IgG production normally begins at the age of two months. A delay in recovery from this physiological hypogammaglobulinemia between the 3rd and the 6th month of life, and of recovery period between 18 and 36 months defines transient newborn hypogammaglobulinemia.
Abnormally reduced ability of T cells to perform their functions in cell-mediated immunity.
Synonyms: Impaired T cell function, T-cell dysfunction

Term: Recurrent infections in infancy and early childhood
Definition: Recurrent infections at an early age with improvement in later childhood.
Hypoplasia of the maxillozygomatic complex.
Synonyms: Decreased size of zygomaticomaxillary bone complex, Deficiency of zygomaticomaxillary bone complex, Hypoplasia of malar bone complex, Hypoplasia of zygomaticomaxillary complex, Underdevelopment of zygomaticomaxillary bone complex

Definition: An increased density in the cranial sutures following obliteration.
The presence of a coronal suture (the cranial suture that separates the frontal and parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Abnormal increased size of the posterior cranial fossa.
Synonyms: Widened posterior fossa

Definition: Abnormally flat (obtuse) angle of the mandible. The angle of the mandibular, located at the junction between the body and the ramus of the mandible, is normally close to being a right angle. This terms describes an abnormal increase of this angle such that the mandible appears flatter than normal.
Synonyms: High mandibular plane angle, Steep mandibular plane angle

Definition: An increase in bone density affecting the calvaria (roof of the skull).
Aplasia or hypoplasia of the paranasal sinuses.
Lack (aplasia) of the ethmoidal sinus.
Synonyms: Agenesis of ethmoid sinuses, Failure of development of ethmoid sinuses, Missing ethmoid sinuses

Definition: Normally, the posterior and lateral fontanelles are obliterated by about six months after birth, the anterior fontanelle closes by about the middle of the second year. This term refers to the situation in which the fontanelles close at an inappropriately early time point.
Synonyms: Early closure of the fontanelles, Obliterated fontanelles

Definition: The presence of calcium deposition in the falx cerebri.
Abnormally increased density of craniofacial bone tissue.
Excessive growth (overgrowth) of the facial bones, that is of the facial skeleton.
Synonyms: Enlargment of the facial bones, Excessive growth of facial bones, Excessive growth of facial skeleton, Hyperostosis of facial bones, Hyperostosis of facial skeleton, Hypertrophy of the facial bones, Increase in size of the facial bones, Overgrowth of facial bones, Overgrowth of facial skeleton, Overgrowth of the facial bones

Definition: Underdevelopment of the frontal bone.
Synonyms: Decreased size of bone of forehead, Hypoplastic frontal bones, Small bone of forehead, Underdevelopment of bone of forehead

Definition: Reduced convexity of the occiput (posterior part of skull).
Synonyms: Flat posterior cranium, Posterior flattening of the skull

Definition: Bony fusion of malleus, incus, and stapes.
Abnormal reduction in ossification of the calvaria (roof of the skull consisting of the frontal bone, parietal bones, temporal bones, and occipital bone).
Synonyms: Poorly ossified calvaria, Poorly ossified calvarium, Soft calvaria, Soft skullcap, Undermineralized calvarium

Definition: The presence of a sagittal suture (the cranial suture that separates the left and right parietal bones) that is not ossified but rather wide open at an age when it is normally closed.
Progressively increasing bone density of the skull base without significant changes in bony contour.

Synonyms: Large frontal sinus

Definition: An abnormally decreased level of immunoglobulin E (IgE) in blood.
Synonyms: Decreased IgE, IgE deficiency

Term: Abnormality of the alternative complement pathway
Definition: A deviation in any aspect of the alternative complement pathway.
An abnormality of the epiglottis.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the epiglottis

Definition: Head circumference which falls below 2 standard deviations below the mean for age and gender because of insufficient head growth after birth.
Synonyms: Acquired microcephaly, Deceleration of head growth, Microcephaly, acquired, Microcephaly, postnatal, Postnatal deceleration of head circumference, Postnatal microcephaly

Definition: A fontanelle that is small for age.
Synonyms: Little fontanelle, Microfontanelle, Small soft spot

Definition: Vertical bony ridge positioned in the midline of the forehead.
Synonyms: Prominent frontal ridge, Prominent metopic suture, Ridging of metopic suture

Definition: The postnatal development of an abnormally large skull (macrocephaly).
Synonyms: Macrocephaly, postnatal

Term: Metopic suture patent to nasal root
Definition: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone in infants and usually fuses by the age of six years. The suture runs from the bregma (the point on the skull at which the coronal suture is intersected perpendicularly by the sagittal suture) to the nasion or nasal root. This term applies if the suture is widely patent from bregma to nasal root.

Term: Midline skin dimples over anterior/posterior fontanelles

Synonyms: Increased erythrocyte osmotic fragility, Increased red cell fragility
Refractory anaemia

Definition: A myeloproliferative disorder characterized by increased proliferation of the granulocytic cell line without the loss of their capacity to differentiate.
Synonyms: Chronic myelocytic leukaemia, Chronic myelocytic leukemia, Chronic myelogenous leukaemia, Chronic myeloid leukaemia, Chronic myeloid leukemia

Definition: Normal adult hemoglobin is composed of two chains each of alpha and beta globin. Hb Barts (Hemoglobin Barts) is a tetramer with four gamma globin chains, and is essentially pathognomonic for one or another form of alpha thalassemia. Hb Barts has an extremely high affinity for oxygen, resulting in almost no oxygen delivery to the tissues.
Synonyms: Haemoglobin Barts, Hb Barts

Definition: Presence of a monoclonal immunoglobulin M protein in the serum.
A transient reduction in the number of erythroblasts in the circulation.
Synonyms: Transient decrease in blood erythrocyte number

Definition: Anemia characterized by abnormal intracellular inclusions, composed of denatured hemoglobin, found on the membrane of red blood cells.
Synonyms: Heinz body anaemia

Definition: A reduction in the ability of neutrophils to kill the gram-positive bacteria, staphylococcus, which is commonly known as staph.
Increased megakaryocyte number, i.e., of platelet precursor cells, present in the bone marrow.
A type of T-cell lymphoma in which cancerous T-cells may present in the blood (leukemia), lymph nodes (lymphoma), skin or in multiple areas.
Larger than normal size of erythrocytes.
Synonyms: Erythrocyte macrocytosis, Increased MCV

Definition: A chronic form of disseminated intravascular coagulation in which a persistent weak or intermittent activating stimulus is present and destruction and production of coagulation factors and platelets are balanced.
Synonyms: Chronic consumption coagulopathy, Compensated disseminated intravascular coagulation

Definition: Disseminated intravascular coagulation is characterized by the widespread activation of coagulation, which results in the intravascular formation of fibrin and ultimately thrombotic occlusion of small and midsize vessels.
A type of sideroblastic anemia that is alleviated by pyridoxine (vitamin B-6) treatment.
Synonyms: Pyridoxine-responsive sideroblastic anaemia

Definition: A malignant lymphocytic neoplasm of B-cell or T-cell lineage involving primarily the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. This category includes precursor or acute lymphoblastic leukemias and chronic leukemias.
Synonyms: Lymphoid leukaemia

Definition: Reduction in the amount of kininogen, which functions as a cofactor in the contact phase of the intrinsic blood coagulation cascade.
Synonyms: Fitzgerald factor deficiency, Kininogen deficiency, Williams factor deficiency, Williams-Fitzgerald-Flaujeac factor deficiency

Definition: A reduced number of hematopoietic cells present in the bone marrow relative to marrow fat.
Synonyms: Bone marrow failure, Bone marrow hypoplasia, Hypoplastic bone marrow

Definition: A type of actue leukemia with features characteristic of both the myeloid and lymphoid lineages. These leukemias are for this reason are designated mixed-lineage, hybrid or biphenotypic acute leukemias.
Synonyms: Acute biphenotypic leukaemia, Biphenotypic acute leukaemia, Myeloid/lymphoid leukaemia, Myeloid/lymphoid leukemia
Macrocytic dyserythropoietic anaemia

Definition: A unique clonal neoplastic disorder that is linked to trisomy 21, is restricted to neonatal period, and spontaneously regresses. It often has characteristics of megakaryocytic lineage and is associated with GATA1 mutations in myeloblasts.
Synonyms: TMD, Transient leukaemia of Down syndrome, Transient leukemia of Down syndrome, Transient myeloproliferative disorder

Definition: A form of hemolytic anemia that can be triggered by exertion.
Average platelet volume below the lower limit of the normal reference interval.
Synonyms: Small platelet size, Small platelets, Small platelets size

Definition: A form of lymphoid leukemia or lymphoma in which too many T-cell lymphoblasts are found in the blood, bone marrow, and tissues. Leukemia or lymphoma classification depends on which feature is more prominent.
A form of poikilocytosis in which the abnormally shaped erythrocytes have notches that results in projections that look like horns.
Synonyms: Distorted red blood cells resembling keratocytes, RBC keratocytosis

Definition: Congenital onset of a marked decrease in the number of granulocytes.
An abnormal prolongation (delay) in the time required by whole blood to produce a visible clot.
Synonyms: Prolonged clotting time

Definition: An abnormality of coagulation related to a decreased concentration of vitamin K-dependent protein C. Protein C is activated to protein Ca by thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. Activated protein C degrades factors VIIIa and Va.
Synonyms: Protein C deficiency

Definition: Proliferation (excess production) of hemopoietically active tissue or of tissue which has embryonic hemopoietic potential.
A reduced count of megakaryocytes.

A chronic lymphocytic/lymphatic/lymphoblastic leukemia (CLL) is a neoplastic disease characterized by proliferation and accumulation (blood, marrow and lymphoid organs) of morphologically mature but immunologically dysfunctional lymphocytes. A CLL is always a B-cell lymphocytic leukemia as there are no reports of cases of T-cell lymphocytic leukemias.
Synonyms: Chronic lymphatic leukaemia, Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia, Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Definition: The frontal suture divides the two halves of the frontal bone of the skull in infants and children and generally undergoes fusion by the age of six. A persistent frontal suture is referred to as a "metopic suture".
An abnormality of the zygomatic arch, also known as the cheek bone.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the malar arch, Abnormality of the zygomatic arch

Definition: A slowly progressing leukemia characterized by a clonal (malignant) proliferation of maturing and mature myeloid cells or mature lymphocytes. When the clonal cellular population is composed of myeloid cells, the process is called chronic myelogenous leukemia. When the clonal cellular population is composed of lymphocytes, it is classified as chronic lymphocytic leukemia, hairy cell leukemia, or T-cell large granular lymphocyte leukemia.
Synonyms: Chronic leukaemia

Definition: Normal hemoglobin synthesis is characterized by production of equal amounts of alpha and beta globins. This term refers to a deviation from this pattern and is the main characteristic of the various forms of thalassemia.
Synonyms: Imbalanced haemoglobin synthesis, Imbalanced Hb synthesis

Term: Abnormality of bone marrow cell morphology
Definition: An anomaly of the form or number of cells in the bone marrow.
Synonyms: Anomaly of the bone marrow cells

Definition: The presence of many cysts in the kidney.
Synonyms: Multiple kidney cysts

Definition: A reduction in the count of nephrons per kidney.
Synonyms: Oligonephronia

Definition: A lack of differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
Synonyms: Absent renal corticomedullary differentiation, Loss of corticomedullary differentiation

Definition: Reduced differentiation between renal cortex and medulla on diagnostic imaging.
Synonyms: Loss of definition of corticomedullary differentiation

Definition: High urine magnesium in the presence of hypomagnesemia.

Synonyms: Increased percent tubular reabsorption of phosphorus

Definition: A type of proximal renal tubulopathy characterized by resorption defects leading to glycosuria, aminoaciduria, tubular proteinuria, renal hypophosphatemia, and urate tubular hyporeabsorption without bicarbonate loss.

A thrombotic microangiopathy with presence of non-immune, intravascular hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and acute kidney injury. A vicious cycle of complement activation, endothelial cell damage, platelet activation, and thrombosis is the hallmark of the disease.
Synonyms: Hemolytic uremic syndrome

Definition: A progressive detrimental connective tissue deposition (fibrosis) on the kidney parenchyma involving the tubules and interstitial tissue of the kidney. Tubulointerstitial injury in the kidney is complex, involving a number of independent and overlapping cellular and molecular pathways, with renal interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy (IF/TA) as the final common pathway. However, IF and TA are separable, as shown by the profound TA in renal artery stenosis, which characteristically has little or no fibrosis (or inflammation). For new annotations it is preferable to annotate to the specific HPO terms for Renal interstitial lfibrosis and/or Renal tubular atrophy.
Synonyms: Tubulointerstitial renal fibrosis

Term: Impaired renal ltubular reabsorption of chloride
Definition: Any impairment of reabsorption of chloride by the kidney in order to not lose too much chloride in the urine.
Synonyms: Impaired reabsorption of Cl, Impaired reabsorption of Cl-

Definition: A duplication of the renal pelvis.
DIsruption and breaking up of the basement membrane of the tubules of the kidney.
Synonyms: Disintegration of the tubular basement membrane

Definition: A type of carcinoma of the kidney with origin in the epithelium of the proximal convoluted renal tubule.
Synonyms: Cancer starting in small tubes in kidneys, Hypernephroma, Renal carcinoma
Patchy hyperpigmentation, Spotty increased pigmentation
Hyperpigmentation of exposed areas, Increased pigmentation in sun-exposed areas

Definition: A focal type of palmoplantar keratoderma in which only certain areas of the palms and soles are affected.
Synonyms: Palmoplantar keratoderma, patchy, Patchy palmoplantar keratoderma
Patchy depigmentation, Patchy hypopigmentation, Spotty decreased pigmentation

Definition: The presence of large spherical melanosomes (1 to 6 micrometer in diameter) in the cytoplasm of melanocytes.

Term: Macular hypopigmented whorls, streaks, and patches

Definition: Telangiectases (small dilated blood vessels) located near the surface of the skin in a butterfly midface distribution.
Synonyms: Butterfly facial telangiectasia
Hair hypopigmentation, Loss of hair color, Loss of hair colour

Definition: The giant congenital nevus is greater than 8 cm in size, pigmented and often hairy. A giant congenital nevus is smaller in infants and children, but it usually continues to grow with the child.
Synonyms: Giant pigmented hairy nevus, Giant pigmented mole, Giant pigmented nevus

Term: Large cafe-au-lait macules with irregular margins
Definition: Large hypermelanotic macules with jagged borders.

Definition: The presence of a bilobed gallbladder, related to a duplication of the gallbladder primordium.

Definition: An abnormally increased rate of skeletal maturation. Accelerated skeletal maturation can be diagnosed on the basis of an estimation of the bone age from radiographs of specific bones in the human body.

Definition: Hyperconvexity of the thoracolumbar spine producing a rounded or humped appearance.

Definition: The ability of the interphalangeal joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.

Definition: An anomalous trapezoidal appearance of a vertebral body. A trapezoid is a four-sided shape that has two sides that are parallel and two sides that are not parallel. In this case, the two lateral sides of the vertebra are parallel, and the top and the bottom are slanted with respect to each other such that the vertebra is shorter in the fron or back than on the other side.

Definition: Absent ossification of the calvaria (vault of the skull).

Definition: The ability of the joints of the hand to move beyond their normal range of motion.
Underdevelopment (hypoplasia) of the third toe.

Definition: The presence of abnormal calcium deposition of the intervertebral disk.
Synonyms: Intervertebral disc calcification, Multiple intervertebral disc calcifications, Multiple intervertebral disk calcifications

Definition: Underdevelopment of the ulna on both sides.
A soft tissue continuity in the anteroposterior axis between the second to the fifth fingers that extends distally to at least the level of the proximal interphalangeal joints.

Definition: Sclerosis (abnormal hardening) of cortical bone, characterized by increased radiodensity.
Moderate osteoporosis.

Definition: Multiple exostoses originating in the fingers and toes.
A foot deformity resulting due to an abnormality affecting the muscle and soft tissue. In contrast if the bones of the foot are affected the term structural foot deformity applies.

Definition: Extreme thickening of the cortex of long bones.
Separation of the odontoid process from the body of the axis.

A tongue-like protusion from the anterior aspect of lumbar vertebral bodies.

Definition: An inherited primary limb malformation disorder characterized by congenital contractures of two or more different body areas and without primary neurologic and/or muscle disease that affects limb function.
Patchy (irregular) increase in bone density. This can take on many forms depending on severity and distribution as can be seen on x-rays.
Synonyms: Patchy increase of bone mineral density, Uneven increase in bone density
Deformed head of long bone in upper arm

Term: Dysplastic distal thumb phalanges with a central hole

Definition: Increased mobility and flexibility in the joint due to the tension in tissues such as ligaments and muscles.

Term: Partial fusion of proximal row of carpal bones

Complete cutaneous syndactyly of second and third toes, Cutaneous 2,3 toe syndactyly, Cutaneous syndactyly of second and third toes, Webbed skin of 2nd-3rd toes

Lethal dwarfism identifiable at birth

The ability of the thumb joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.

Definition: An abnormal irregularity of cortical bone.

Term: Spinal stenosis with reduced interpedicular distance

Definition: Underdevelopment (reduced size) of the tibia.

Term: Avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis
Definition: Avascular necrosis of the proximal epiphysis of the femur occurring in growing children and caused by an interruption of the blood supply to the head of the femur close to the hip joint. The necrosis is characteristically associated with flattening of the femoral head, for which reason the term coxa plana has been used to refer to this feature in the medical literature.

Definition: An increase in bone density affecting the basicranium (base of the skull).

Definition: Absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fourth finger.

Synonyms: Diffuse, symmetrical osteosclerosis, Generalised osteosclerosis, Osteosclerosis, diffuse symmetrical

Bilateral hypoplasia of condylar process of mandible, Bilateral hypoplasia of mandibular condylar head, Bilateral hypoplasia of mandibular condylar neck, Decreased height of condylar process of mandible, Decreased length of condylar process of mandible, Short condylar process of mandible

Definition: Abnormal thickening of the cortex of the diaphyseal region of long bones.

Definition: In type E brachydactyly, shortening of the fingers is mainly in the metacarpals and metatarsals.

A pathologic entity characterized by a developmental defect in a long bone leading to bending and pathologic fracture, with inability to form a normal bony callus with subsequent fibrous nonunion, leading to the pseudarthrosis (or "false joint").
Synonyms: Pseudoarthroses

Definition: A form of triphalangeal thumb that can be placed opposite the fingers of the same hand.

Synonyms: Fused 4th-5th long bones of hand, Fused 4th-5th metacarpals, Fused fourth and fifth metacarpals, Ring finger and little finger metacarpal synostosis, Synostosis of the fourth and fifth metacarpal bones

Definition: An enchondroma is a benign growth of cartilage that develops within the medullary cavity of bone. Enchondromatosis refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas, and this term refers to the presence of multiple enchondromas within the medulla of metaphyseal bone. Radiographically an enchondroma presents a an oval, linear, or pyramidal osteolytic (radiolucent) lesion with well defined margins.
An abnormality of skeletal development characterized by a disturbance of the metaphysis and its histological structure with relatively normal epiphyses and vertebrae.
Disproportionately short middle and distal phalanges compared to the hand/foot.
Synonyms: Progressive brachydactyly of middle and distal phalanges, Short middle and distal phalanges of digits ii through v

Definition: Combined syndactyly and polydactyly of the great toe.

Definition: Progressively worsening joint contractures.

Definition: Abnormality of one or all of the epiphyses of the phalanges of the hand. Note that this includes the epiphysis of the 1st metacarpal. In contrast to the metacarpals 2-5, the first metacarpal is embryologically of phalangeal origin and as such equivalent to the proximal phalanges of the digits 2-5 (whereas the proximal phalanx of the thumb is equivalent to the middle phalanges of the other digits).
Any structural anomaly of the hand.

Abnormalities of the metaphyses of the hand, Abnormality of the wide portion of the hand bone

Definition: Any abnormality of the epiphyses of the phalanges or metacarpal bones.

Term: Aplasia/hypoplasia involving bones of the hand
Definition: Absence (due to failure to form) or underdevelopment of the bones of the hand.

Bone fusion involving the calf bones
Bone fusion involving the shinbone

Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis (DIP) is characterized additionally by thickend alveolar septa and by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate that often includes plasma cells and occasional eosinophils. The alveoli are lined by plump cuboidal pneumocytes. Lymphoid aggregates may be present.

Definition: Acidosis because of respiratory retention of carbon dioxide.

Reduced intestinal absorption of fructose. Breath testing after ingestion of fructose has been widely adopted as a standard method of identifying fructose malabsorption and intolerance. A dose of 25 g of fructose dissolved in a 10% solution is generally accepted as the appropriate dose of fructose for clinical use of H2 and CH4 breath testing. High levels of hydrogen in exhaled breath subsequent hours indicate fructose intolerance. Presence of malabsorption and reproduction of symptoms during a breath test provides the best objective evidence and symptom correlation for fructose intolerance.

Definition: Intermittent episodes of ketoacidosis.

Central Y-shaped metacarpals may be seen as a result of a central polydactyly with partial fusion of the duplicated metacarpal.

Term: Swan neck-like deformities of the fingers
Definition: A swan neck deformity describes a finger with a hyperextended PIP joint and a flexed DIP joint. The most common cause for a swan neck-like deformity is a disruption of the end of the extensor tendon. Conditions that loosen the PIP joint and allow it to hyperextend, for example conditions that weaken the volar plate, can produce a swan neck deformity of the finger. One example is rheumatoid arthritis. Another cause are conditions that tighten up the small (intrinsic) muscles of the hand and fingers, for example hand trauma or nerve disorders, such as cerebral palsy, Parkinson's disease, or stroke.

The term proximal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the middle and proximal phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the proximal interphalangeal finger creases.

Definition: Radial dysplasia, also known as radial longitudinal deficiency, includes radial clubhand and is a disfiguring, and potentially disabling, congenital limb anomaly. The entire upper limb may be involved, although the defect is most evident in the forearm and hand. Affected children suffer a variable degree of hypoplasia or absence of the preaxial skeleton and soft tissues, in particular the thumb, radius, and dorsoradial soft tissues. The hand is usually radially deviated and subluxated off the distal aspect of the ulna, the ulna may be shortened and have a bow-shaped deformity, and there is no true wrist (radiocarpal) joint in Bayne2 type-III and IV radial dysplasia.

Definition: Tracheal diverticula are blind-ended outpouchings arising from the trachea. They are usually an incidental finding. Occasionally they can mimic pneumomediastinum. Tracheal diverticula are either congenital or acquired, in the latter case the most common causes are prolonged increased intraluminal pressure, e.g. chronic cough, COPD, tracheomalacia, and iatrogenic (e.g. post-surgical).

Synonyms: Laryngeal stidor

Definition: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis involves inhalation of an antigen. This leads to an exaggerated immune response and a following inflammation of the alveoli within the lungs. The main feature of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis on lung biopsies is expansion of the interstitium by lymphocytes accompanied by an occasional multinucleated giant cell or loose granuloma. After exposure to the provoking antigen, following symptoms can be seen: fever, chills, malaise, cough, hemoptysis, chest tightness, dyspnea, rash, swelling and headache and can be completely reversible, based on the duration of the illness, categorized as acute (HP:0011009), subacute (HP:0011011), and chronic (HP:0011010).
Accumulation of amorphous PAS-positive material in the space betweem alveolar macrophages, sometimes as condensed form (oval bodies) are typically found in alveolar proteinosis.
Synonyms: Alveolar proteinosis, Detection of PAS-positive extracellular material in broncho-alveolar lavage, Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis

Definition: Substantial narrowing or blockage of small pulmonary veins as a result of disorganized smooth muscle hypertrophy and collagen matrix deposition.
Synonyms: Pulmonary venous stenosis

Definition: Adenocarcinoma of the Bronchus.

Abnormal dilatation of the pulmonary lymphatic vessels. Lymphatic fluid in the lung is derived from normal leakage of fluid out of the blood capillaries in the lung. In pulmonary lymphangiectasia, the pulmonary lymphatics are not properly connected and become dilated with fluid.
Synonyms: Pulmonary lymphangiectasis
Repeated pneumothorax

Definition: Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis is a benign lymphoproliferative disorder of the lung that is characterized by the presence of a dense, predominantly lymphocytic interstitial infiltrate (lymphocytes, plasma cells, other elements of the lymphoreticular system) that expands the alveolar septa.
Synonyms: Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis, Lymphoid interstitial pneumonia, Lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis

Definition: According to the definitions of the American and British Thoracic Societies, including pulmonary functional tests, X-rays, and CT scans for items such as fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bullae, emphysema, nodular or lymphomatous abnormalities.
Synonyms: Chronic lung disease

Definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary lymphatic chain.
Abnormality of the lung parenchyma extending to the pulmonary interstitium and leading to diffuse pulmonary fibrosis.
Synonyms: Abnormal lung parenchyma morphology, Abnormality in area between air sacs in lung, Interstitial lung disease, Interstitial pulmonary disease

Definition: An increased susceptibility to pneumonia as manifested by a history of recurrent episodes of pneumonia.
Synonyms: Multiple pulmonary infections, Pneumonia, recurrent, Pneumonia, recurrent episodes, Pulmonary infection, Pulmonary infections, pulmonary infections, recurrent, Recurrent pneumonia, Recurrent pulmonary infections

Definition: A recurrent hemorrhage occurring within the lung.
Synonyms: Recurrent bleeding into lungs, Recurrent intrapulmonary haemorrhage, Recurrent pulmonary haemorrhage, Recurrent pulmonary hemorrhage

Definition: Obstruction of conducting airways of the lung.
Synonyms: Obstructive lung disease, Pulmonary obstruction

Definition: An increased susceptibility to bronchopulmonary infections as manifested by a history of recurrent bronchopulmonary infections.

Synonyms: Underdevelopment of the bronical cartilage

Definition: A type of pulmonary sequestration that is completely enclosed in its own pleural sac, occurring above, within, or below the diaphragm, and without communication with the tracheobronchial tree.

Pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, a condition most commonly associated with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, is an abnormal communication between the pulmonary artery and pulmonary vein without an intervening capillary communication. HRCT images usually show a coarse spidery appearance of the peripheral vascular markings in the lungs. More specific findings are obtained in the pulmonary angiogram where the normally invisible capillary phase is replaced by irregular vascular channels bridging the peripheral branches of pulmonary arteries and veins.
Synonyms: Pulmonary AV malformation
Primary pulmonary dysgenesis, unilateral

Definition: Hepatic failure refers to the inability of the liver to perform its normal synthetic and metabolic functions, which can result in coagulopathy and alteration in the mental status of a previously healthy individual. Hepatic failure is defined as acute if there is onset of encephalopathy within 8 weeks of the onset of symptoms in a patient with a previously healthy liver.
Synonyms: Acute liver failure

Definition: A diffuse form of hepatic steatosis.
Synonyms: Hepatic steatosis, diffuse

Term: Decreased mitochondrial complex III activity in liver tissue
Definition: Decreased activity of complex III of the mitochondrion in the liver.
The presence of abnormal calcium deposition in the liver.
Synonyms: Liver calcifications

Definition: Hyperplasia of the biliary tree, as manifested by increased size of bile ducts, dilated lumen, and histologically by an increased number of epithelial cells or hyperplasia.
Synonyms: Bile duct hyperplasia

Definition: Inflammation of the liver due to infection with a virus.

Term: Malformation of the hepatic ductal plate

Definition: Intermittently increased size of the liver.
An abnormal increase in the amount of intracellular lipid droplets in hepatocytes.
An increase in the amount of glycogen stored in hepatocytes compared to normal.
Synonyms: Increased liver glycogen content

Term: Reduced number of intrahepatic bile ducts
Definition: The presence of reduced numbers of intrahepatic bile duct than normal.
Synonyms: Hepatic ductopenia

Definition: An acute form of hepatic steatosis.
Synonyms: Acute fatty liver
Liver arteriovenous malformation
Liver vascular malformations

Definition: A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of large regenerative nodules.

Neonatal jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and other tissues of a newborn infant as a result of increased concentrations of bilirubin in the blood. Neonatal jaundice affects over half of all newborns to some extent in the first week of life. Prolonged neonatal jaundice is said to be present if the jaundice persists for longer than 14 days in term infants and 21 days in preterm infants.
Synonyms: Neonatal jaundice, Prolonged yellowing of skin in newborn

Definition: Fibroblast proliferation and fiber expansion from the portal areas to the lobule.

Term: Depletion of mitochondrial DNA in liver
Definition: An abnormal reduction in the number of mitochondria in hepatocytes.
Repeated occurrences of acute noninflammatory encephalopathy and fatty degenerative liver failure.

Synonyms: Fatal liver failure in infancy
Small abnormally formed scapula, Small abnormally formed shoulder blade

Definition: The two portions of the clavicle (corresponding to the two primary ossification centers of the clavicle) are connected by a fibrous bridge that is contiguous with the periosteum, and a synovial membrane develops, resulting in a clavicle with a bipartite appearance radiographically. Congenital pseudarthrosis of the clavicle generally presents as a painless mass or swelling over the clavicle.
Synonyms: Clavicle pseudoarthrosis, Pseudoarthrosis of clavicle

Definition: An abnormally straight configuration of the clavicle, a tubular bone which normally is doubly curved .
Synonyms: Straight collarbone
Flaring of lower rib cage

Definition: Prematurely closed sternal sutures.
Synonyms: Prematurely closed sternal sutures

Definition: Lack of development of the glenoid fossa, also known as the glenoid cavity, which is the articular surface of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus.
Synonyms: Aplasia of the glenoid fossa

Definition: Bony fusion between the humerus and scapula, leading to an impairment in mobility of the affected shoulder joint.
Synonyms: Fusion of shoulder blade to long bone in upper arm, Humero-scapulo synostosis, Humeroscapular synostosis, Synostosis of shoulder joint
Restricted chest movement

Definition: The presence of a paralyzed diaphragm.
Synonyms: Diaphragmatic paralysis, Paralysed diaphragm, Paralyzed diaphragm

Term: Irregular ossification at anterior rib ends

Synonyms: Flared, irregular rib ends

Definition: Irregular surface of the normally relatively smooth border between the distal part of the ribs and the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage that connect the ribs to the sternum.
Synonyms: Irregular costochondral margins

Definition: Early ossification of the costochondral junction, which is the joint between the ribs and costal cartilage in the front of the rib cage.
Underdevelopment of the middle portion of the clavicle.
Synonyms: Underdeveloped middle portion of the collarbone

Definition: A larger than usual distance between the left and right nipple.
Synonyms: Wide-spaced nipples, Widely spaced nipples, Widely-spaced nipples

Term: Decreased number of sternal ossification centers
Definition: A less than normal number of sternal ossification centers. The sternum is initially formed from bilateral sternal plates that chondrify and begin to fuse with ribs at 10 weeks gestational age. Ossification starts in the manubrium and upper part of the sternal body at the 6th month, in the middle of the sternal body at the 7th month, in the lower part of the body during the 1st postnatal year and in the xiphoid process between years 5 and 18. The number of ossification centers vary up to six, and it is the ossification centers that are visualized by prenatal ultrasound. This term describes a reduction in the number of ossification centers compared with age-related norms.
Synonyms: Decreased number of sternal ossification centres

Definition: Lack of formation and mineralization of the ribs in utero.
Synonyms: Absent rib calcification in utero

Definition: Deposition of calcium salts in point-like foci within the anterior portion of one or more ribs.
Abnormal increase in density of the tissue at the costochondral junctions.
Synonyms: Sclerotic costochondral joints

Definition: Breast carcinoma that is bilateral or otherwise multifocal.
Synonyms: Multifocal breast cancer

Definition: Lack of formation of mineralized bony tissue of the sternum.
Synonyms: Absent sternal mineralization, Lack of sternal ossification
Small distal segments of the shoulder blade, Underdeveloped outermost segments of shoulder blade

Definition: Underdevelopment of the glenoid fossa, which is the cavity in the lateral part of the scapula which articulates with the head of the humerus.
Synonyms: Glenoid hypoplasia, Hypoplastic glenoid fossa

Definition: Osteosclerosis of ribs (increased density related to increased bone mass).
Synonyms: Increased bone density in ribs

Definition: Developmental defect resulting in congenital absence of the middle portion of the clavicle.
Synonyms: Missing middle part of collarbone

Definition: More than one fracture of the ribs.
Synonyms: Multiple rib fractures
Prominent floating ribs
Large sternal ossification centres
Fused sternal ossification centres

Definition: Abnormally reduced diameter (cross section) of the clavicles.
Synonyms: Thin collarbone

Definition: Calcification of the costal cartilages, which are bars of hyaline cartilage found at the anterior ends of the ribs which serve to prolong the ribs forward and contribute to the elasticity of the walls of the thorax.
Synonyms: Cartilaginous ossification of rib

Definition: Chest wall pain in the area of the costochondral junctions.
Synonyms: Costochondral junction pain

Term: Thickening of the lateral border of the scapula
Synonyms: Thickening of the lateral border of the shoulder blade
Hypoplastic first rib, Hypoplastic first ribs, Small first rib, Underdeveloped first rib
Internally rotated shoulders

Definition: Absence of the clavicles as a developmental defect.
Synonyms: Absent clavicles, Absent collarbone, Aplastic clavicles

Definition: An abnormal morphology of the ribs consisting of shorted, abnormally curved ribs. On posteroanterior chest radiography, the ribs show a curvature resembling that of a coat hanger (clothes hanger).
Synonyms: Coat hanger sign of ribs
Small twelfth rib, Underdeveloped twelfth rib

Definition: Increased time for the complex comprised of the Q wave, R wave, and S wave as measured by the electrocardiogram (EKG).. In adults, normal values are 0.06 - 0.10 sec.
Synonyms: Intraventricular conduction delay, Prolonged QRS complex on EKG, QRS widening

Definition: Inflammation of the coronary arteries involving a granulomatous response, i.e., a non-specific inflammatory response involving granulomas, defined as a compact organized collection of mature mononuclear phagocytes including epithelioid and giant cells.

Premature ventricular contractions (PVC) or ventricular extrasystoles are premature contractions of the heart that arise in response to an impulse in the ventricles rather than the normal impulse from the sinoatrial (SA) node.
Synonyms: Extra heart beat, Premature ventricular beat, Premature ventricular contractions, Ventricular ectopics, Ventricular extrasystoles, Ventricular premature beat

Definition: An abnormality of filling of a ventricle with blood during diastole.

Term: Ventricular preexcitation with multiple accessory pathways
Definition: A form of ventricular preexcitation due to the presence of multiple accessory pathways for cardiac conduction.
The presence of excessive connective tissue in the endocardium.
Synonyms: Endomyocardial fibrosis

Definition: Abnormal tortuous (i.e., twisted) form of the aorta.
A bacterial infection of the endocardium, the inner layer of the heart, which usually involves the heart valves.
Synonyms: Infective endocarditis

Definition: Calcium deposition in the myocardium.
Synonyms: Calcified myocardium

Term: Short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve
Definition: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the tricuspid valve.
Steatosis in the myocardium.

Term: Early progressive calcific cardiac valvular disease

Definition: A defect of the atrioventricular septum of the heart.
Synonyms: Atrioventricular septal defect, Endocardial cushion defect

Definition: A localized outpouching of ventricular cavity that is generally associated with dyskinesia and paradoxical expansion during systole.
A type of cardiac arrhythmia with premature atrial contractions or beats caused by signals originating from ectopic atrial sites.
Synonyms: Atrial ectopic beats, Atrial premature complex, Ectopic supraventricular rhythms, PACs, Premature supraventricular beats

Definition: Acute occurrence of a dissection (tear within the tunica intima and entry of blood into the tunica media) of a coronary artery.

Synonyms: Absent/small lungs, Absent/underdeveloped lungs

Definition: Any structural abnormality of the coronary arteries.
An abnormality of an atrioventricular valve.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the atrioventricular valves

Definition: An abnormality of the hepatic vasculature.
Synonyms: Abnormality of liver blood vessels, Abnormality of the liver vasculature
Absent/rudimentary nipples, Absent/small nipples, Absent/underdeveloped nipples, Nipples absent or rudimentary

Definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the clavicles (collar bones).
Synonyms: Absent/small collarbone, Absent/underdeveloped collarbone

Term: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving bones of the thorax
Synonyms: Absent/small outermost thorax bone, Absent/underdeveloped thorax bone
Absent/small ribs, Absent/underdeveloped ribs, Hypoplastic or missing ribs
Absent/small shoulder blade, Absent/underdeveloped shoulder blade
Absent/small sternum, Absent/underdeveloped sternum
Tympanic nerve tumor, Tympanic nerve tumors, Tympanic nerve tumour, Tympanic nerve tumours
Benign gastrointestinal tract tumours, Benign GI tract tumors, Benign GI tract tumours, Non-cancerous GI tumors, Non-cancerous GI tumours

Definition: A form of acute leukemia characterized by excess lympoblasts.
Synonyms: Acute lymphatic leukaemia, Acute lymphatic leukemia, Acute lymphoblastic leukaemia, Acute lymphocytic leukaemia, Acute lymphocytic leukemia, Acute lymphoid leukaemia, Acute lymphoid leukemia

Definition: The presence of an adenocarcinoma of the pancreas.
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia of T-cell origin. It comprises about 15% of childhood cases and 25% of adult cases. It is more common in males than females.
The presence of an follicular adenocarcinoma of the thyroid gland.
A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma in which the papillae are covered by large eosinophilic cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and nuclear pseudostratification.
A rare subtype of acute myeloid leukemia evolving from primitive megakaryoblasts.
Synonyms: Acute megakaryocytic leukaemia, AMegL

Definition: The presence of an adenoma in the cortex of the kidney.
Synonyms: Kidney cortical adenoma

Definition: Pheochromocytoma not originating from the adrenal medulla but from another source such as from chromaffin cells in or about sympathetic ganglia.
Synonyms: Pheochromocytoma, extraadrenal

Term: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
Definition: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin is a malignant tumor of squamous epithelium.
Synonyms: Squamous skin carcinoma

Term: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder
Definition: The presence of a carcinoma of the urinary bladder with origin in a transitional epithelial cell.
Synonyms: Transitional cell bladder carcinoma

Definition: A malignant neoplasm of the adrenal cortex that may produce hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, estrogen, or testosterone.
Synonyms: Adrenal carcinoma, Adrenal gland carinoma

Definition: Pheochromocytoma originating from the adrenal medulla.
Synonyms: Pheochromocytoma, adrenal, Pheochromocytomas, adrenal
Malignant gastrointestinal tract tumours, Malignant GI tract tumors, Malignant GI tract tumours

Definition: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the stomach.
Synonyms: Stomach tumor, Stomach tumour

Definition: The presence of leiomyosarcoma of the skin.
The presence of a malignant neoplasm of the genital system.
Synonyms: Malignant genitourinary tract tumour, Malignant GU tract tumor, Malignant GU tract tumour

Definition: The presence of a carcinoma in the renal pelvis.
A slowly growing malignant neoplasm derived from cartilage cells.
The presence of renal cell carcinoma in the renal papilla.

A type of pituitary adenoma originating in prolactin secreting cells. This kind of adenoma is characterized by overproduction of prolactin, and may cause loss of menstrual periods and breast milk production in women.
Synonyms: Pituitary prolactinoma, Prolactin-secreting pituitary adenoma
Localised neuroblastoma
Myxoid subcutaneous tumours

Definition: A subtype of renal cell carcinoma thought to originate from mature renal tubular cells in the proximal tubule of the nehpron.
Synonyms: Nonpapillary renal cell carcinoma

Definition: A malignant epithelial tumor with a glandular organization that originates in the duodenum.
A benign renal neoplasm composed of fat, vascular, and smooth muscle elements.
Synonyms: Angiomyolipoma, Kidney angiomyolipoma

Definition: The presence of a papillary adenocarcinoma of the ovary.
A malignant plasma cell tumor growing within soft tissue or within the skeleton.
A non-malignant neoplasm of the genitourinary system.
Synonyms: Benign genitourinary tract tumor, Benign genitourinary tract tumour, Benign GU tract neoplasm

Definition: A malignancy of the parathyroid glands. Parathyroid carcinoma usually secretes parathyroid hormone, leading to hyperparathyroidism.
Synonyms: Parathyroid Cancer

Definition: A kind of thyroid adenoma characterized by the presence of oxyphil cells.
Underdevelopment of the paranasal sinuses.
Synonyms: Decreased size of paranasal sinus, Decreased volume of paranasal sinus, Underdevelopment of paranasal sinus

Definition: Muscular dystrophy affecting the muscles of the limb girdle (the hips and shoulders).
Synonyms: limb girdle muscular dystrophy

Term: Loss of ability to walk in first decade
Synonyms: Loss of ability to walk in first decade
Cystic lesions in the basal ganglia

Definition: Any anomaly of the anterior horn cell.
Synonyms: Abnormality of the anterior horn cells, Anomaly of the anterior horn cells, Anterior horn cell disease

Definition: Reduced amount of myelin in the nervous system resulting from defective myelinogenesis in the white matter of the central nervous system.

Term: White mater abnormalities in the posterior periventricular region

Definition: A type of focal clonic seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking rapidly involves one side of the body at seizure onset.
Synonyms: Hemiclonic seizure, Hemiclonic seizures, Unilateral clonic seizure, Unilateral clonic seizures

Definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum.
Synonyms: Cerebellar vermis aplasia/hypoplasia, Hypo/aplastic vermis

Definition: A form of lissencephaly in which the cortex is thickened and has four more or less disorganized layers rather than six normal layers resulting from incomplete neuronal migration during brain development. At neuropathological examination, a 4-layered cortex consists of an upper molecular layer, a second thin cellular layer containing pyramidal neurons usually observed in layer V, a third pale poorly cellular layer and a fourth thick deep layer made up of neurons which had failed to migrate. Radiologocally would manifest as agyria or pachygyria with cortical thickness greater than 10 mm.
Synonyms: Classic lissencephaly, Four-layered lissencephaly, Lissencephaly, type I, Type 1 lissencephaly, Type I lissencephaly

Definition: A type of polymicrogyria with a gradient of severity (anterior more severe than posterior) extending from frontal poles posteriorly to precentral gyrus and inferiorly to frontal operculum.
Synonyms: Polymicrogyria, anterior to posterior gradient
Cranial nerve palsies, Cranial nerve palsy, Cranial nerve paresis

Term: Pallor of dorsal columns of the spinal cord
Definition: An abnormally pale appearance of the dorsal portion of the gray substance of the spinal cord. This finding can be observed by histological examination.

Synonyms: Degeneration of the spinal cord

Definition: A severe degree of muscular hypotonia characterized by markedly reduced muscle tone.
Synonyms: Hypotonia, severe, Severely decreased muscle tone

Term: Developmental stagnation at onset of seizures
Definition: A cessation of the development of a child in the areas of motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and/or emotional skills, following the onset of epilepsy.
A type of Horner syndrome with congenital onset.
Absence of the knee jerk reflex, which can normally be elicited by tapping the patellar tendon with a reflex hammer just below the patella.
Synonyms: Absent knee jerk reflex

Definition: Developmental defect characterized by a small and malformed corpus callosum.
Underdevelopment of the ventral portion of the pons.
Synonyms: Underdeveloped ventral pons

Definition: Multiple neurofibromas of the spinal nerve roots with a symmetric distribution.
Synonyms: Spinal nerve root neurofibromas, symmetric, multiple

Definition: The occurrence of repeated episodes of generalized muscular hypotonia.
Synonyms: Episodic generalised hypotonia

Definition: Wasting (atrophy) of the vermis of cerebellum.
Synonyms: Atrophy of cerebellar vermis, Atrophy of the cerebellar vermis, Vermian atrophy

Definition: A loss or impairment of the sensation of the relative position of parts of the body and joint position occuring at distal joints.
Synonyms: Distal sensory loss of proprioception

Definition: A severe delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.

Term: Sensorimotor polyneuropathy affecting arms more than legs

Synonyms: Midline CNS lipomas

Definition: A type of holoprosencephaly in which most of the right and left cerebral hemispheres and lateral ventricles are separated but the most rostral aspect of the telencephalon, the frontal lobes, are fused, especially ventrally.
Underdevelopment of the cerebrum.
Synonyms: Small cerebrum, Underdeveloped cerebrum

Definition: A symmetric and progressive loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
Atrophy affecting the pons and the cerebellum.
Synonyms: Cerebellopontine atrophy

Definition: A hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum.
Synonyms: Hemangioblastoma, sporadic cerebellar

Definition: A diffuse loss of myelin from the internode regions along myelinated nerve fibers of the peripheral nervous system.
A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the distal portions of the limbs.
Synonyms: Decreased distal vibration sense

Definition: The term progressive intellectual disability should be used if intelligence decreases/deteriorates over time.
Synonyms: Intellectual disability, progressive, Mental retardation, progressive, Progressive mental retardation

Definition: Borderline intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 70-85.
Synonyms: Intellectual disability, borderline, Mental retardation, borderline

Definition: Atrophy (wasting, decrease in size of cells or tissue) affecting the frontotemporal cerebrum.
Synonyms: Cerebral atrophy, frontotemporal

Definition: Fleeting perceptual experiences that occur during the transition from sleep to wakefulness.

Malfunction of the abducens nerve as manifested by impairment of the ability of the affected eye to be moved outward. Patients who develop abducens nerve palsy often present with binocular horizontal diplopia, which is a double vision when looking at objects side by side. There will be a notable weakness of the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle leading to a deficit in of eye abduction on the affected side. Some patients may present with a constant head turning movement to maintain binocular fusion and to lessen the degree of diplopia.
Synonyms: Abducens nerve palsy, Abducens nerve paralysis, Abducens nerve paresis, Cranial nerve VI palsy, Lateral rectus muscle denervation paresis, Sixth nerve palsy

Definition: The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures that is present already at the time of birth.
Atrophy of the frontal cortex.
Synonyms: Frontal cortex degeneration
Inability to walk by childhood/adolescence

Term: Intraaxonal accumulation of curvilinear autofluorescent lipopigment storage material
Definition: Curvilinear intracellular accumulation of autofluorescent lipopigment storage material within axons.

Term: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behavior
Synonyms: Abnormal aggressive, impulsive or violent behaviour

Definition: Stiffness (a condition in which muscles cannot be moved quickly without accompanying pain or spasm) of the axial musculature.
Excessive number of small gyri (convolutions) on the surface of one side of the brain.

Brain damage related to a lowering of blood glucose below a critical level (around 30 mg/dl), which may lead to confusion, lethargy and delirium followed by seizures and coma. Prolonged hypoglycemia may lead to irreversible brain damage.
The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cortex of frontal lobe and the cortex of parietal lobe.
Pericallosal lipomas are congenital soft masses of adipose cells encapsulated by a thin layer of fibrous tissue, appearing adjacent to the corpus callosum of the brain.
Synonyms: Lipoma of corpus callosum

Definition: Nystagmus dating from or present at birth.

A reduced sense of touch (tactile sensation) on the skin of the distal limbs. This is usually tested with a wisp of cotton or a fine camel's hair brush, by asking patients to say 'now' each time they feel the stimulus.
Synonyms: Decreased distal touch sense, Decreased touch sensation in extremities

Definition: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration at the ankles. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to the malleoli of the ankles.
Synonyms: Decreased vibration sense at ankles, Decreased vibration sense in feet, Impaired vibration sensation at ankles

Definition: A complete loss of the ability to perceive vibration.
Synonyms: Apallesthesia

Definition: An increased susceptibility to meningitis as manifested by a medical history of recurrent episodes of meningitis.
Hypoplasia of the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.

Synonyms: Dilatation of lateral cerebral ventricles, Dilation of lateral ventricles, Enlarged lateral ventricles, Lateral ventricle dilatation

Definition: An abnormality of the auditory evoked potentials, which are used to trace the signal generated by a sound, from the cochlear nerve, through the lateral lemniscus, to the medial geniculate nucleus, and to the cortex.
Synonyms: Abnormal brainstem auditory-evoked potentials

Definition: Proximal spinal muscular atrophy, i.e., muscular weakness and atrophy related to loss of the motor neurons of the spinal cord and brainstem.
The presence of calcium deposition in the choroid plexus.
Synonyms: Calcified choroid plexus
